B000B8QEZG|2.0|This makes two clunkers in a row for Madonna. First, \\"American Life\\" proved to be a ho-hum album from one of our least boring musical personalities. <br />Now, \\"Confessions\\" continues that streak, as she returns to her dance/disco ways, but without any of the charm, any of the fun, any of the drama, any of the sexiness, or any of the great melodies and rhythms that she has given us over the last two decades. <br /> <br />The best thing on this album is \\"Hung Up\\", and it doesn't hold a candle to the jittery swagger of \\"Don't Tell Me\\" or the epic sweep of \\"Ray of Light\\". <br /> <br />Listen...you go to a dance club, and you'll hear continuous music all night long. This album is sequenced in that fashion; the songs fade into each other. While you're dancing, you'll hear songs you may or may not recognize. <br /> <br />The music will keep you going, right? It doesn't matter if you know the song...if the groove is on, you'll keep going. Every once in a while, a song will pop up that just kills the moment...it's boring; it's the wrong tempo...it's just not worth dancing to, and you'll go sit down. <br /> <br />Other songs are so amazing, you'll do anything you have to, to stay on the dance floor. Even if you're dancing with the ugliest, sweatiest, most foul-smelling creature on the planet, you won't leave until that song is over. <br /> <br />And then there are those in the middle, which are fine to dance to, yet if you really needed another drink or a bathroom break, it would be \\"OK\\". <br /> <br />This album has no songs that would keep you glued to the dance floor, and several that would usher you off. Most of it is pleasant enough.  <br />And if \\"pleasant\\" is one of the adjectives you use to best describe a Madonna record, you know you're in a bit of trouble. <br /> <br />I like the lyrics of \\"I Love New York\\", but I wish they had better support.  <br /> <br />\\"Isaac\\" might have been the album's classic track, yet the Middle-Eastern elements sounds forced and really don't benefit the song at all. This isn't like Sting's \\"Desert Rose\\". Here it sounds awful. That's quite a shame because the remainder of the song sounds pretty cool... <br /> <br />The album has a lot of producers...and normally I don't mind that. Here though, you really couldn't tell. It all sounds pretty much the same...heterogeneous...so why have three or four producers? Where's the variety, the flavor? <br /> <br />I have been fascinated with Madonna since her boy-toy days. Her continual re-invention has become the model for the modern pop star.  <br /> <br />She has taken risks, she has often failed but more often has blown us out of the water. Her sexy, provocative, luscious younger self has evolved into a more angular, lithe, muscular figure. She has flirted with most all musical trends, starting several of them herself. The moment one thinks her career is on the wane, she explodes with a killer single, an amazing album or a tour that defies expectations.  <br /> <br />She has been irresistible. <br /> <br />Until recently. I was lucky enough to see her on her last tour, and loved it. I went back to see why I clearly misjudged \\"American Life\\", and I found that I had not. <br /> <br />It still bored me to tears. And this from somebody who is embarrassed to admit that he enjoyed her cover of \\"American Pie.\\" <br /> <br />When did Madonna become utterly \\"resistible\\"?

0765309408|5.0|In my biennial foray into the Science Fiction genre, Scalzi's first novel came highly recommended by Amazon's algorithms. As a huge fan of Heinlein and, especially, Starship Troopers, Old Man's War promised a similar terrain of interstellar warfare spearheaded by Earth and mankind. <br /> <br />Scalzi doesn't disappoint. His clever, to-the-point plot introduces John Perry, a widower just turned 75. By dint of his age, Perry is now eligible to join the Colonial Defense Forces, a shadowy crew pledged at expansion of mankind's footprint throughout the galaxy. Perry doesn't have much to lose, after all. Though details of his transformation into a CDF soldier remain classified on Earth, he's lost his beloved wife and is fully aware of his diminishing physical and mental abilities. <br /> <br />After signing up for what appears to be a two-year stint, he soon finds out that his term is going to be closer to a decade. But he'll have the body to match. His physical transformation into a super soldier -- no spoilers here -- is truly remarkable. But he'll need every bit of his new capabilities because the enemies arrayed against humankind are powerful, enigmatic, and quite violent. <br /> <br />Scalzi has woven together compelling technical details (the physics behind the interstellar \\"skip\\" drive), including genetic engineering, the tactics of interstellar warfare, human-computer interfaces, and robotics into a first-class story. Fans of Starship Troopers won't be disappointed. And those who relish Heinlein stories will be clamoring for more Scalzi.

0452282152|3.0|I'm a sucker for historical fiction. Gary Jennings' Aztec and Ken Follett's Pillars of the Earth are probably the most enjoyable examples of period fiction based upon historical fact (with plenty of author's license utilized, to be sure). For an educator, historical fiction is a great way to introduce the study of a period without the usual commensurate pain. <br /> <br />Chevalier's Girl with a Pearl Earring was laying around our house (required reading by my 16 year-old for her AP history class, I believe). The reviews on the back cover were stunning: the Times, Journal, Chronicle and others waxed eloquently; depicting the novel as a compelling blend of 17th century Holland, the paintings of Dutch master Johannes Vermeer, and the origins of one of his most famous paintings. <br /> <br />The painting is, of course, \\"Girl with a Pearl Earring,\\" also known as \\"the Mona Lisa of the north.\\" An enigmatic young woman is featured in the painting (and on the book's cover). She is imagined by Chevalier to be one of Vermeer's maids named Griet. Griet is shy, intelligent, and too-pretty-for-her-own-good. Forced into servitude by her father's unexpected blindness, Griet becomes an essential part of Vermeer's busy household. <br /> <br />Cleverly navigating the domestic politics of a household spilling with children, a grandparent, and other maids, Griet soon finds herself receiving attention not only from Vermeer's wealthiest patron but also the great master himself. How she deals with these difficulties forms the very essence of the book. <br /> <br />Unfortunately, the book's plot is so simplistic as to be almost 233 pages of nothingness. Imagine a Seinfeld episode taking place in the 17th century without any humorous characters, and you've pretty much got the idea. As for 17th century Holland, consider it unvisited. There were few details that would satisfy the mildly curious, not to mention someone truly interested in the period. Despite an elegant writing style, this bookcould have been the length of a magazine article without missing a beat.

B00005JKLZ|4.0|I must confess that I march to a different drummer when it comes to this film.  I enjoyed it for the most part, and find it very clever in many aspects.  The major drawback comes from the plot - it is far too simplistic for the elaborate care that went into both the visual aspect of the film as well as the nice touches at almost every turn.<br /><br />The plot is rather simple - Alexander Hartdegen, a mechanical physics professor in turn-of-the-century New York (turn of the nineteenth-into-the-twentieth century, that is), has his head in his equations, apart from one thing, his love for Emma.  When she is killed in a botched mugging (yes, New York at that time even had muggings in Central Park), Hartdegen drops everything to invent the time machine he'd theorised, in order to prevent Emma's death.  He soon makes the discovery that it isn't possible to undo the past (at least not that aspect of the past), but becomes obsessed with finding the reason why.  He speculates this is more likely to be answered in the future than in the past or present, and thus goes forward in time.  He makes a few stops along the way before arriving at a far-distant future (nearly a million years in the future), in which the human race has evolved into two distinct species - one on the surface, and one below the earth.<br /><br />So far, so good - departure from H.G. Wells' original classic (a great piece of literature) and from the earlier film, but not beyond the pale.  The effects here are truly stunning in many respects - the time machine itself is a marvel (the DVD has a feature on the making of the machine), and the time transformation scenes are very inspiring, up to and including the zoom-away shot from the machine into the air all the way to the city on the moon.  The Eloi city along the river is also a remarkable scene.  The movie rightly won awards, including the Academy Award, for these effects.  Unfortunately, effects do not a movie make.  This is where the plot failure comes into play.<br /><br />Hartdegen seems to give up far too early in trying to change the past, and his relationships (such as we get to see them) in the future are very stilted.  Jeremy Irons (himself an Academy Award winner) has precious little screen time, to deliver what is perhaps the most anticlimactic resolutions I've seen in a long time.  The overarching question should be 'why?', but seems to transformed into 'what if?' in an unclear way (the deleted introductory scene, available on the DVD, helps to more firmly establish the question, but, alas, it was deleted).  Hartdegen remains in the future (like Wells' and the earlier film's scientists, albeit in a different way), perhaps to help transform the future, but we'll never know (a sequel is not likely).<br /><br />Despite the thin plot, what I found most enjoyable (apart from the special effects) were the clever touches here and there, far too numerous to mention.  When Hartdegen arrives in 2030 (prompted by an advertisement proclaiming 'the future is now'), he encounters a user-friendly library computer (personified by Orlando Bloom) with a real sense of humour and humanity.  When Hartdegen asks about time travel, the library computer even incorporates Star Trek gestures and sound effects into its discussion (as well as the yet-unwritten musical version of 'The Time Machine', by Andrew Lloyd Weber).  One woman in the distant future speaks English (now called the stone language, for the stone engravings that remain from store fronts and the like), but speaks without accent (strange enough, but even stranger that New Yorker Hartdegen sounds more British, as does the Morlock leader Jeremy Irons).<br /><br />Indeed, there are so many little pieces here is seems that the writers spent more time trying to incorporate bits of cleverness throughout the script than making sure the script as a whole had thorough soundness.<br /><br />Another piece I really liked was the music.  The sombre brass tones, the triumphant orchestral arrangements, the folk/modern synthesis for the Eloi, and the dramatic scoring really enhanced this film beyond measure.  The DVD has bits of the score that replay on a loop sequence during menu screens, and I've sometimes left these on to hear the pieces over and over again.<br /><br />The DVD has one of the better menu sequence set-ups I've seen, simulating the machine effects in visuals and sound, as well as incorporating score elements and special effects.  DVD extras include the delete scene, commentaries by many of the crew, several pieces on the special effects (including one on the time machine itself),<br /><br />This is a fairly good film, despite its flaws.  Overall I would award it three-and-a-half stars, but will round up to four in honour of the effects, the music, and clever pieces., the triumphant orchestral arrangements, the folk/modern synthesis for the Eloi, and the dramatic scoring really enhanced this film beyond measure.  The DVD has bits of the score that replay on a loop sequence during menu screens, and I've sometimes left these on to hear the pieces over and over again.   <br /> <br />The DVD has one of the better menu sequence set-ups I've seen, simulating the machine effects in visuals and sound, as well as incorporating score elements and special effects.  DVD extras include the delete scene, commentaries by many of the crew, several pieces on the special effects (including one on the time machine itself),  <br /> <br />This is a fairly good film, despite its flaws.  Overall I would award it three-and-a-half stars, but will round up to four in honour of the effects, the music, and clever pieces. <br />
B000AQBA1W|5.0|Jean and Gerry Corr were two 1970s amateur musicians from Dundalk, County Louth (Ireland) who performed traditional Irish music alongside covers of songs popular at the time. The couple's four children later grew up to become one of the best-selling sibling acts of all time, combining rock and roll with traditional Irish elements such as fiddle, tin whistle, and bodhran. After fifteen years of worldwide success, the quartet known for their pop tunes and ballads has returned to their roots to give fans a taste of home - their home.     The Corr siblings (Jim - guitar and piano; Sharon - violin; Caroline - percussion; Andrea - tin whistle and vocals) perused their late mother's Irish songbook and recorded some of her favorites along with tunes they cherished while growing up. While each song featured on the album is exquisite, some simply stand out:    'My Lagan Love': The album's opening track is the epitome of Irish ballads, combining pining lyrics with a beautiful yet tragic melody. The story of love and longing near the River Lagan (which flows through Belfast), it is as much a song capturing the spirit of Northern Ireland as a traditional tune.    'Heart Like A Wheel': \\"It's only love that can break a human being and turn him inside out,\\" sings Andrea on this tender piano ballad. Beautifully performed, it is at once uplifting and heart-wrenching.    'Buachaill On Eirne': The band once commented in an interview that they did not remember much Gaelic from their school years, but upon listening to \\"Buachaill On Eirne (Boy From Ireland)\\", one would hardly know. The track is heartwarming, full of exuberant energy and tender lyrics, performed in the Emerald Isle's first tongue. Without a doubt, my favorite tune on the album.    'Old Hag': During the last fifteen years, the Corrs have toured the world, sharing traditional Irish jigs with audiences from Sydney to Singapore to San Francisco. \\"Old Hag\\" is such a jig, easily danceable, and an instrumental that will have youclapping along as if you were sharing a pint in a Dublin pub.    After four best-selling studio albums, the Corrs have gone back to their roots with \\"Home\\". It's a record filled with Irish charm and heart, and from start to finish there isn't a bad track. Each song has been tenderly recorded, and each of them will capture your heart, giving you a taste of the Emerald Isle the band calls Home.
B000AXSN5G|5.0|Well I can't give this album 6 stars, but I would like to.  Are there any musicians who have lasted as long as Neil Young and still produced good music?  I don't think so.  I've listened to so many other claims as to what might be the \\"Best Album of 2005\\" or \\"Best Album of the Year\\", but they all fall short compared to this album.  Neil Young is heartwarming and yet melancholy, passionate yet detached in this album.  It is easily the best album of the year, and possibly one of the best albums I've ever listened to.  For someone like me, who has become so disenchanted with modern \\"rock\\" in any form, country rock, hard rock, whatever the hell, it really takes an amazing album to make me return to any music that has guitar.  Leave it to Neil Young to bring me back to reality.  For a work of true genius and pure emotion by one of the greatest musicians of all time, go get this CD and enjoy it as much as I have.  I could go on and on, but for those who have short attention spans, I will end this review here.

B000002UAR|5.0|A lot of people will probably agree that this is some of the Beatles' best work. The introduction of new instruments into rock (string quartetts and the sitar) and the exploration of new sonic textures bring the personality of these tracks alive. But the most important things, as I can see in this album, are consision, cohesion and completeness. These were made possible not by drugs however, but by the maturity of the Beatles' approach.    This is the last Beatles album where the songs followed these standards in the 2 or 3 minute pop-song tradition. The difference, however, is in the quality and depth of the musical ideas themselves. While \\"I wanna hold your hand,\\" and \\"She Loves You\\" are fun and dancable numbers, Revolver's tracks show an effective skill at quickly and simply conveying a range of emotions. \\"Love You To,\\" is an urgent song about the fears of life ending before the chance to enjoy it. \\"I Want to Tell You\\" achieves an unusual effect by combining affectionate lyrics with music that almost borders on the ominous and fearful. The gloom and heaviness of a church cemetary is conveyed perfectly in the pulsating strings of \\"Eleanor Rigby.\\"    Proably the most unusual song, however, is \\"She Said She Said\\". It opens with its theme on a solo guitar, a theme that guides the entire song. It is a song that both musically, and lyrically, asks a question and leaves no answer. \\"She said I know what it's like to be dead . . . and shes making me feel like ive never been born . . . Even though you know what you know, I know that I'm ready to leave, cause youre making me feel like I've never been born.\\" This song supposedly was inspired by an LSD-intoxicated conversation between Lennon and Peter Fonda, who said these things to Lennon, making Lennon feel strange and uncomfortable with staying. The listener is confronted with the same ideas in this song, and as Lennon sings the theme one last time in the words \\"She said,\\" it simply repeats, and the song fades away, leaving the question unanswered. In two minutes and thirty four seconds a simple theme has become a haunting reminder of a question that we are afraid to ask ourselves, and one that continues to echo in our memory long after the song has ended.    The Beatles would not remain creative in this way for long. They would go on to break many barriers, to introduce the bizarre and unorthodox into rock, and to open the floodgates for a new revolution of drug music. This can be seen even here, on \\"Tomorrow Never Knows.\\" However, although some people would disagree, I see this as a decline rather than an awakening. \\"I am the Walrus,\\" \\"Helter Skelter\\" and \\"Revolution Nine ('No. 9')\\" are striking and powerful songs, but they do not have the masterful craftwork of the songs on Revolver. It would be a tragedy to think, as I know many people do, that the creativity and expression of Revolver can be attributed to drug intoxication. On the contrary, it was the muddled miscommunication in the band that was influenced by this drug use for the most part, a practice that helped to ultimately end the band's career. It was not their drugs that made this album possible, but their spirit. This spirit helped them grow from the four moptops they used to be, albeit helping them become the four stoners. Even the coincidental role of LSD in \\"She Said She Said\\" was used in a mature and creative way, not a way that indulges an \\"anything goes\\" shock value a la The White Album.    Revolver remains a tribute not to the opportunities that the celebrated subatances opened for these four musicians, but for the ones they closed.
B00001OH7O|5.0|This is the first Bowie album I bought. After that I ended up buying almost all his albums, but I must say that none of Bowie's other albums(except maybe Ziggy Stardust) had the impact this one had on me. Some songs on this album are extremely beautiful and show Bowie's undeniable genius. This album will not leave you indifferent, you'll remember it for the rest of your life. I also think it's not a bad introduction to the Bowie catalogue, it will leave you so amazed that you will want to own every Bowie album (next step is Ziggy Stardust) or at least that's what happened to me. Go buy it, it's worth the money.

0800141601|4.0|For movie buffs that have been brought up on the usual chronicles on the legend of King Arthur, the story of this movie would be a digression. While the other stories center on Arthur, his conquests and his governing his subjects, this movie's story focuses more on the Guinevere's ambivalence towards Arthur and Lancelot; to some this may be a storyline unheard of. <br /> <br />Guinevere is sent to Camelot to marry King Arthur. Her party is attacked on the way by Malagant (called Meliagaunce in the legendary stories ); and Lancelot, now a wayfarer, saves her. She then reaches Camelot shortly before Lancelot reaches there. As fate would have it, things happen to make them meet and come together. Now, she is in a very sensitive position - her heart is torn between her love for Arthur and her attraction towards Lancelot. What happens then forms the rest of the movie. King Arthur, played well by Sean Connery, is much older than Guinevere. Lancelot is played by Richard Gere. <br /> <br />The battles, sword fights, chases on horsebacks etc, are well choreographed and shot. In fact they help keep the pace and the realism of the movie, considering the fact that not much of and about castles or keeps are shown in the movie. <br /> <br />It has a planned story line, believable role play by Sean Connery (King Arthur), Julia Ormond(Guinevere), and Ben Cross (Prince Malagant who is always dressed in black to denote that he is the antagonist); well shot chase/battle scenes, and an admirable musical score by Jerry Goldsmith. Speaking of music, all the theme music in this movie are wonderful, to listen in the movie, or listen as they are, removed from their context. All in all it is a movie worth watching and appreciating.  <br /> <br />If you ever get a chance to see it I recommend it. Great for vacation watching.
B00005JOIF|5.0|Steven Spielberg again strikes a raw nerve in his somber tribute to his Jewish heritage in \\"Munich\\". He recounts the massacre of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics by the Palestinian terror group Black September.  Using archived film clips from news reports of the terrorist attack he creates a graphic portrait of the horror generated by this event.  Using a clever cinematographic technique his color film appears to be more a colorized black and white, a washed out, toned down version of the vibrant color schemes seen in todays films.<br /><br />Eric Bana, previously seen playing Hector in \\"Troy\\" gives a career defining performance as low level Israeli Mossad agent Avner Kaufman.  Bana is recruited through the highest channels of Israeli government including prime minister Golda Meir to administer revenge for the Olympic attacks.  Bana is separated from his family and made head of a five man assassination team to execute 11 Palestinians identified as being responsible for the attacks.  He is officially made a non entity in Israel so that his actions can have deniability.<br /><br />Included in his team among others is Daniel Craig playing British accented Steve.  Bana is handled by his Mossad contact Ephraim played nicely by Geoffrey Rush.<br /><br />The plot lead us through the machinations Bana and his team have to go through to accomplish their mission.  They are assisted by a family of Frenchmen lead by the distinguished Michael Lonsdale who provide information for exorbitant fees as to the whereabouts for their targets.<br /><br />Spielberg presents a fairly unbiased view of these events also evoking sympathy for the Palestinian cause.  Bana's character in the film, Avner goes through a metamorphosis. his psyche ultimately in turmoil due to guilt and the paranoia of his position. He and his family leave Israel to settle in the U.S..  We realize that although he is beseeched by Rush to return to his homeland, things can never be the same for him there.r him there.
B000AP04FG|2.0|I've had high expectations for this film for so long now. And what happened? I was disappointed. Not with Angelina, she was fabulous as always, but Brad pulled the whole film down around him.<br /><br />This is basically True Lies, but without the greatness that was True Lies. Even down to the tango dance scene. But while True Lies had terrific action scenes from the start, this film starts with marriage counselling (much like in When Harry Met Sally), and Brad comes across as really stupid. It drags most of the way through, broken up with lots of shoot outs, and a highly unbelievable car chase section.<br /><br />There's something about Brad that I've never got. Every other woman out there swoons whenever he appears, but there's just no appeal there for me. Just a wee bit in Thelma & Louise, but I've never felt it in any other film. He's just too clean cut, but I can see why he may have been enticed for Angelina. Who wouldn't? But his character, and now him in real life, is unlikeable. He's lost whatever magic he used to have that every other woman could see, and I can't.<br /><br />Angelina only just about saves this film, and although it's not one of her best, it's still good to watch her. The girl knows she's hot as hell, and can do just the simplest thing to make a guy or girl swoon. I'm straight, I have a boyfriend, but if Angelina was offering ... Whereas Brad knows too damn well that women think he's sexy, and it's gone straight to his head. He's so cocky it's unbelievable.<br /><br />There's a few tongue in cheek jokes, but the only one I really got was the fact John Smith mentioned he'd been married once before, in Vegas. Angelina & Billy Bob did get married in Vegas. I think that's what it meant, although it maybe me jumping to conclusions.<br /><br />Vince Vaughn appears in what looks like an extended cameo, and he's irritating as hell. I don't know what's going there, but his character was pointless, and could have been written out quite easily, and never been missed.<br /><br />There's no real ending to this movie, and you're left with the feeling that there should be something more, with the Smiths shooting at nothing, and not getting hit at all. Some of the action scenes can come across as quite dodgy, especially when John Smith gets stabbed in the leg, pulls it out, with barely a grimace, and then runs. Uh huh of course.<br /><br />I wouldn't recommend this film, unless you're an Angelina fan, and willing to sit through a not great film just to watch her. If you're that desperate, then sure go ahead. Just don't say I didn't tell you. Thankfully I didn't pay money for this. I got it as a Christmas present. B000000YG5|5.0|I'll weigh in on the Rollins vs. Coltrane issue.  When I first discovered jazz 30 years ago I fell under the Coltrane spell.  I couldn't get enough of him, wore out two copies of Live at the Village Vanguard.  As I got older I began to prefer the clarity of ideas, mastery of rhythm and melodic storytelling of the great Sonny Rollins.  Now there is no contest.  I agree with those who believe that Sonny is the greatest improviser of the last 50 years, or more.  Every cut on Saxophone Colossus is a jewel.  Blue 7 was famously analyzed by musicologist Gunther Schuller as a model of almost architectural structure in improvised music.  I prefer to think of it as melodic storytelling.  Nobody does it better than Sonny Rollins.  This record is one of the finest in jazz, in 1956, now or 100 years from now.
1594200653|5.0|I have to chime in and agree with the numerous reviewers who have bemoaned the lack of footnotes and bibliographical citations in this book.  I'm sure that Tony Judt and his publisher didn't take the decision to adopt such radical departure from the academic norms lightly, but the choice is simply wrong, and lamentable.  Steering readers towards a website that contains the missing footnotes seems foolish and naive: yes, it, in the short term it may fill in the blanks and will save many trees from the pulp mill... But what is the likelihood that this website will still be online in five or ten years?  Rather slim, I would think.  And though future versions of the book may include either the missing footnotes, or some other technological fix, this original edition will be judged flawed and incomplete for years to come.  A pity, since it is a major historical work, and quite satisfying in all other regards.
006054094X|5.0|Gavin Menzies has shaken the world of history like no one else in recent years with a radical new theory: that the Chinese discovered most of the world between 1421 and 1423 and that in the process were responsible for a vast number of hitherto unexplained historical anomalies that previous theorists have attributed to everything from ancient Atlantis to aliens from outer space.  Now while this has the singular advantage of better satisfying Occam's Razor, which can perhaps be most usefully stated: \\"when you have two competing theories which make exactly the same predictions, the one that is simpler is the better\\", it needs to be stated that Menzies uncovers no \\"smoking gun\\", no single piece of evidence that proves his theory.  Instead he accumulates a mountain of circumstantial evidence (of admittedly varying quality) and attempts to prove his case by sheer weight.<br /><br />Despite the hysterical reaction by an embarrassing number of historians (who are starting to make ranting Evolutionist responses to Creationism and Intelligent Design look scientific by comparison) there seems little doubt that Menzies' theory is PARTLY correct.  There also seems little doubt that some of his interpretations of some of the evidence are flat out wrong, as his critics gleefully point out, acting as if they've proved something.  But with a circumstantial case like this, calling into question 1 or 10 or 50 of his points doesn't discredit the rest.  Menzies is clearly trying to provoke additional research into the subject, not prove every single one of his assertions correct.  He doesn't mind if you approach his theory full of skepticism as long as you do so with an even partially open mind.  This is clear on his web site (somewhat obviously 1421 dot tv) where he not only details theories so questionable he left them out of the book, but also encourages people to watch a documentary [[ASIN:B0002IQNF6 1421 - The Year China Discovered America]] that first presents his theory and then savages it.<br /><br />There's not much question who has the more open mind or the more scientific approach between Menzies and his fiercest critics, and there's also not much question that the Chinese got further around the world than current historians are willing to admit.  The question is just how much further, and hopefully after they've finished venting, Menzies' critics will get to work researching it, too.<br /><br />Note: since it contains updates, corrections, and revisions, you will want to pick up the paperback [[ASIN:006054094X 1421: The Year China Discovered America]] rather than the hardback [[ASIN:0060537639 1421: The Year China Discovered America]]; however, the appendices have been substantially reworked with some information dropped entirely so if you can find a hardback edition in good shape for a bargain price, this is one time it might be worth getting both.it.    There's not much question who has the more open mind or the more scientific approach between Menzies and his fiercest critics, and there's also not much question that the Chinese got further around the world than current historians are willing to admit.  The question is just how much further, and hopefully after they've finished venting, Menzies' critics will get to work researching it, too.    Note: since it contains updates, corrections, and revisions, you will want to pick up the paperback [[ASIN:006054094X 1421: The Year China Discovered America]] rather than the hardback [[ASIN:0060537639 1421: The Year China Discovered America]]; however, the appendices have been substantially reworked with some information dropped entirely so if you can find a hardback edition in good shape for a bargain price, this is one time it might be worth getting both.

0446577383|2.0|I have never read Baldacci before, and have no plans to in the future after reading \\"The Camel Club\\". The only reason I even bothered to finish it was at the insistance of a friend who loaned it to me.  I am eternally grateful that I am not lamenting having actually spent money on it. <br /> <br />Reading \\"The Camel Club\\" is akin to grading the essay theme of an English lit major finishing in the middle of his class.  His descriptors are just laughable.  The main character of a homeless man turned ex-special forces killer reluctant hero just does not ring true.  There are so many improbabilities and outright proposterus scenarios that one just throws up the hands for any sense of reality.   <br /> <br />There are no adequate words to describe how bad this book is.  Check it out at a library, or borrow it from a friend.  Stuart Woods is more entertaining.  Tom Clancy is more intellectual and detailed.  And Steven King is more compelling.  Given Baldacci's published successes, he cannot be as bad as \\"The Camel Club\\" makes him appear.

When I finally did, the film surprised me with its powerful, emotional acting and characterization. It also imparted some good values without coming across as preachy. In terms of depth, it was also much better than Mona Lisa Smile, or Music of The Heart (both of the same genre). All in all, highly entertaining, feel-good film which unlike most Hollywood movies, also imparts a dose of good values.

B00079018K|4.0|Why is everyone complaining about the copy-protection that Sony had to slap on so people won't steal the music? I agree that Sony doesn't need to do this, and they are being idiots. So let's get on with the reviewing as I review this great album, Kasabian.    MY REVIEW  __________________________    I first found out about Kasabian through 'word of mouth', though the words spoken weren't nessecarily good ones. [...] My friends and I are in love with The Strokes, and somebody attacking Julian Casablancas, Singer/Songwriter for The Strokes infuriated me. I figured I'd listen to some of this 'crap' just to spite it.     I hate it when I'm wrong. Kasabian is a great album by a great band. I, too, am a fan of the Madchester scene, when bands like The Stone Roses and Happy Mondays were still around. The days just after my all-time favorite band Duran Duran entered its '...wow.' period, and the days just before my all-time favorite band Blur entered its '...wow!' period. The revival of said scene has led to bands like The Killers and Bloc Party, while bringing the return of great bands like Depeche Mode and Duran Duran. One of the bands coming to this great 'new New Wave' scene was Kasabian, mixing the personality of Oasis with the musical talents of Blur (Think Tank period). When they finally released an album, many Oasis fans and Blur fans...and fans of every band inbetween was pleased.    'Club Foot' is a great opener with a booming bass line accompanied by heavy vinyl-esque drums and an Liam Gallagher-like-singer whose...'confidence' can be sensed in his vocals. 'You can't take control of me...you're messing with the enemy' are only a few lines of this great song. 'Processed Beats' is another good song, but the chorus gets on my nerves. Its okay, though. I loved 'Reason Is Treason'...until it was featured on everyone's favorite show, the show that clearly makes every band mainstream , 'The OC'. Honestly, why is that show still on the air? 'I.D.' seems like it could fit in a soundtrack very well, it's dark and deep.    'Orange' is just a transition/it's sort of a filler song, the end of the song is the beginning to  'Lost Souls Forever' which was used in the movie 'Stealth'. It's a great song with vintage sweeping synths and distorted drum beats. From then on we have 'Running Battle', whose title doesn't really fit the song. Let's just say it's not the fastest song, but it's okay. 'Test Transmission' is a song filled with little bleeps and bloops. From then on we have funny little 'Cutt Off', slow and heavy 'Butcher Blues', new-waveish 'Ovary Stripe', all leading up to the 10:50 long 'U Boat', starting off with an odd sound effect and then a swirly synth with Tom's edgy vocals. Guitars come in at about the one-minute mark, but the song doesn't kick in until 2 minutes, with a great tambourine effect.    I think this is a great debut album and would reccomend it to any fans of this type of music. Try it out, you'll probably like it.
B000058983|5.0|Years ago when I picked up a book that ranked the best albums of all time, I had a great shock when I found this album at #1.  Could it possibly be better than the #2 \\"Pet Sounds\\" or even the #3 \\"Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band\\"?  Fueled by a combination of curiosity and utter disbelief, I decided to get the cd and lo and behold, I was blown away.<br /><br />The music was unlike anything I had ever heard before and it was obvious from the start that this was a very original work of art and that Arthur Lee was a brilliant genius at work.  It became clear to me as well that \\"Forever Changes\\" is very deserving of its lofty ranking.  A simply beautiful album and probably as close as pop music has ever come to being high works of art.<br /><br />Now this version has been very well remastered and for the diehard fans, 7 very interesting bonus tracks have been added.  As a guitarist myself, I personally found the track in which Arthur Lee chastises his guitarist for playing only in one range of the guitar to be the most insightful.  The guitarist, clearly rattled, goes on for a second take which Arthur pronounces as great work but if you listen closely is clearly compositionally and musically not as good as the first solo that Arthur panned!<br /><br />Yes, it was a lot louder and was full of hammer-ons and pull-offs and what guitarists call cliches full of sound and fury but really nothing much in terms of substance (he even plays a couple of wrong notes that are clearly out of key) but I was amused to see Arthur impressed by that and the guitarist giving him what he wanted even if it was musically inferior to the first solo.  It was to me, a clear lesson in delegation and empowerment and letting people who are expert at what they do do their own thing.  Highly recommended.

B00005NGZX|4.0|Like their previous (and following) works, Converge's eighth album, 2001's \\"Jane Doe,\\" is super hard to describe and even more difficult to categorize. It is a very meticulously constructed, emotional, complex, and dissonant record which sounds more like cats in a blender than actual music. Don't get me wrong--it is still very memorable, but not because it has radio-ready, tuneful, hooky songs. The fiery, relentless, pounding guitars and absolutely sick drumming (by Ben Koller) make the rhythms flattening and not very pleasing to the ear. What separates Converge from the rest of the math metal/noisecore pack is the vocals. Even in those all-too-rare moments when the guitars are metalcore-esque (i.e. tracks six, nine, and ten have chugging riffs), Jacob (Bannon)'s tortured, atonal, very high-pitched, monkey-like shrieks make \\"Jane Doe\\" unique and almost deafening. Tracks two and eleven, \\"Fault And Fracture\\" and \\"Thaw,\\" best illustrate Ben's insane, all over the place, careening drum work, and \\"Distance And Meaning\\" has machine gun snare drums. Other highlights include the explosive riffs and crashing drums of \\"Concubine\\" the pounding guitar chords and cracking snare drum on \\"Bitter and Then Some,\\" and \\"Heaven In Her Arms,\\" which has a strong, propulsive guitar lead throughout. These songs are pretty much all the same, because the only real attempt at actually having a rhythm comes during song number four, \\"Hell To Pay,\\" when the song begins with soft guitar strumming, before becoming a catchy, galloping rhythm. \\"Jane Doe\\" is certainly not for everyone. If you enjoy catchy, accessible songwriting and arrangements, you'll have absolutely no luck with this album. And if you want a C.D. that you can sing along to and hum in your mind all day long, you'll definitely have to look elsewhere. But if you like mathcore and/or listen to bands like Norma Jean, Dillinger Escape Plan, Meshuggah, Black Dahlia Murder, and/or Burn the Priest, and if you want a mind-scrambling, brain-melting sonic assault, then you've bought the right C.D.melting sonic assault, then you've bought the right C.D.
B000089RVX|5.0|I first heard My Immortal on the car radio, and thought `wow, who was that?' At the time I was convinced it was some new English folk-influenced act: I was gobsmacked when a friend told me that Evanescence were an American metal band! Later, I saw the equally impressive Bring Me To Life video and realised that this was the same band I had heard on the radio. <br /> <br />I've bought many albums on the strength of a couple of songs, and frequently been disappointed. Not this time! Fallen passes my acid test for a true classic album - the natural tendency to just put it on and press the play button - no thought whatsoever of track selection. There really isn't a duff moment: thunderous riff-driven, but melodic rock, with portentous classical flourishes (I sense a debt to Tony Iommi here); timely changes of tempo and dynamics with two beautiful piano-led reflective ballads (My Immortal and Hello); thought-provoking dreamlike lyrics, Amy Lee's dramatic Celto-Gothic persona, and all the time those incredible vocals - sometimes ethereal, sometimes searing and soaring above the mix. <br /> <br />Despite its dark, minor key, symbolic and brooding themes, this album has the apparently perverse ability to lift my mood (witness the several thousand people with grinning faces mouthing the words 'I want to die!' along with Lee each time the band perform Tourniquet live!) The best new music I've heard in the last five years, it's never out of the CD player for very long. I can't wait for next year's follow up, but am seriously troubled by the effect on the songwriting the sad departure of Lee's collaborator Ben Moody might have.
B00000JCB2|4.0|When Limp Bizkit released \\"Significant Other\\" in 1999, they were not only very popular, but almost everyone thought they were a promising young band who showed real, credible songwriting skills. Now, I'm not a Limp Bizkit fanatic, but the truth about this album is, if you listen to it with an open mind, you should realize it is actually pretty good. Gratuitous profanities and self-absorbed lyrics (which littered later Limp Bizkit releases) aren't present, here, and some songs (like \\"Re-Arranged,\\" \\"No Sex,\\" and \\"A Lesson Learned\\") have introspective lyrics which are actually pretty mature! Plus, in addition to being very catchy and somewhat exciting, \\"Significant Other\\" has a variety of songs, so it covers all of the bases. \\"Just Like This\\" is a nearly danceable intro track, while songs like the infamous \\"Nookie,\\" \\"Breakstuff,\\" and \\"I'm Broke\\" are quite mean, energetic, and heavy. \\"N 2 Gether Now\\" is a full fledged rap song (with a guest spot from members of Wu Tang Clan), \\"Don't Go Off Wandering\\" is somewhat creepy, \\"Show Me What You Got\\" is a kiss-off which seems made to get the mosh pits swirling, and \\"A Lesson Learned\\" is a very slow, depressing, partially a capella ballad. This might not be saying much, but \\"Significant Other\\" is Limp Bizkit's finest hour. It's a good album, it is arguably rap-rock at its finest, and it actually proves that Limp Bizkit know how to write a few good songs. So you have my approval to go ahead and buy this album (especially if you have Nineties nostalgia)...just don't tell any of your friends.

B000B8QEYC|4.0|For Enya fans there is always a long wait between her albums. Those albums really combine that trademark Enya sound along with some celtic inspired sounds and that is what is missing somewhat on this new album. B000002KIE|5.0|<br />\\"I dont get it\\", said John, \\"all we want to do is destroy everything.\\"  <br /> <br /> <br />This is my first Amazon review. I am just trying to do my part in straightening out all the rubbish that is connected with the Sex Pistols. In my 17 short years on this earth, I have tried to make some sense of possibly the most misunderstood word, movement and musical genre ever; Punk.  <br /> <br />Okay, first of all I'll begin by stating all the reviews of this album have to be of the lowest standard out there (as this album is so widely known and so limitly understood correctly) and the word poser appears a couple hundred times to many. I'd like to clear up a few things aswell. Yes, this album is fairly simple musically, like most punk bands debut albums are, but, also like other great punk bands (and probably more so in this than any) you can sense something greater than any complex chord progression can achieve, and you get a hint of great things to come and a taste of something higher than talent. Obviously the Pistols didnt have great things to come as a band, for reasons to complicated to go into now (try \\"The Filth and the Fury\\"), but the Clash ceertainly did (also the Ramones and Bad Religion) and that sense is equally as abundant in their classic punk rock debut, and look how talented they became. I believe it to be complete resentment that enables absolute individual creativity to arise, and that was what English punk was all about.  <br /> <br />With all the lies that circulate around this band, im going to try to work as best i can with the facts. Punk doesnt start, nor end with the Sex Pistols, but they did play a major role in shaping it. No one can claim to have 'invented' Punk as music isnt invented, it evolves.  <br /> <br />The sound is obviously derived from rock 'n' roll with The Stooges being the first band to be clearly different (released their debut in 1969). Then came the first wave of 'punk', from America a few years later; New York Dolls,Richard Hell and The Ramones. I consider the Ramones the most 'punk' of these as their music is more stripped down raw rock 'n' roll than the rest. If you were to say one band invented punk it would definetly be the Ramones, as they had already released two albums by the time most other Punk bands had released any.  <br /> <br />Then came the UK Punk, which I consider of higher standards than the American Punk. It was also in the UK I believe that whole 'punk image' was created, by 'the Johns', John Lydon and his friends (all named John). With their American influences (apparently Punk kicked off in the UK after the Ramones toured there) a band was formed by angry working class boys who called them selves the Sex Pistols. And the UK Punk movement began, and an explosion of anger was release upon a very, very unprepared world.  <br /> <br />This is as clearly as I can put my understanding of Punk as a genre: there are two types, English and American. American came first but was quickly drowned out by the English scene. The English punk was more openly angry and quite more juvinille than the Americans. The two biggest bands from both scenes would be the Ramones from America and the Pistols from England. The Ramones were about taking everything bad in their lives and celebrating it, with their 'bubble gum' tunes, and the Pistols on the other hand, were about taking everything bad in their lives, finding the source of it, then absolutly offending the hell out of it. These are both Punk but in quite different ways. Both bands (and scenes) were fed up, both were angry youths, both were legends and revolutionised music and the world.  <br /> <br />The major thing that seperates the two scenes is their image. The Ramones were nothing new really, but the Pistols... they were something brand new indeed. As I stated earlier, the punk image in London was initiated by the Johns. Malcolm Maclaren and the pre-Lydon Pistols were looking for a head man and spotted John and asked himto audition, he agreed and after the audition was accepted into the band. John Lydons individual way of thinking, and utter hatred, was what sparked his unique image and song writing abilities. And the rest is history, the Pistols changed the world, sparked the punk movement in London and continue to influence bands nearly 30 years later, now not many bands can claim that.  <br /> <br />Now, from what I have read and viewed, the Pistols were just another band before John joined, so to say he made the Pistols, I dont think is too far from the truth, just look at what happened to them after he left. I really think John influenced the rest of the band a lot, becasue i know he has greatly influenced me, and many other bands have stated he influenced them too. All this talk of Malcolm making the Pistols is nonsense, Malcolm didnt make anything, even 'his' shop was directed by Vivian Eastwood.  <br /> <br />Being born 15 years after the punk movement, it was hard to understand it, but the brilliant documentary, 'The Filth and the Fury', helped, a lot. The state of England in the 70's was only 100% clear after viewing this, and this has helped my value the Pistols a lot more. From the rage that was built up inside them from basically everything around them; the 'fake' pop bands, the government and the royal family, came a semi-unique sound, but energy that is unparralled by anything i have ever heard before, and since.  <br /> <br />I like the Clash, a lot, and the Buzzcocks and the Ramones and Bad Religion, but while i think the music of the Clash is far superior to the Pistols, the sheer power of the Sex Pistols is overwhelming and i think it is that, that will always keep me coming back for more. Its clear the Pistols were not brilliant musicians, but they were young and still learning. Glen had probably the most talent, which is why even after he left the band, they still hired him as a session player.  <br /> <br />The Pistols were some-what about provoking, but mostly i believe they were about promoting change, becasue obviously they were fed up with the old way. In John's book, 'Rotten: No Irish, No Blacks, No Dogs' he denys the Pistols ever being nihilistic, which i can totally undestand. 'God Save The Queen' is by no means nihilistic, 'Anarchy in the UK' is some-what, but thats the provokotive genius of John Lydon. For me the thing that makes the Sex Pitsols so much better than the rest, is that they sound so different, especially Johns voice.  <br /> <br />Now, to hate something, first you must completly understand it. All these one star reviews are obviously by kids hooked on the pop tones of Good Charlotte and Simpley Plan, who obviouly dont understand the first thing about what Punk is, or what it means to be Punk. There is no point asking people to stop one-star-reviewing becasue there is no stopping the stupid.  <br /> <br />So you can drop the rating on here all you like, because seriously, it means nothing. Everybody who loves this album understands the brilliance of it, and everyone who doesnt like it, doesnt understand it at all. But if your just looking to get into the Pistols, or Punk in general, start with the greatest, probably the most influencial and inspirational album ever created. I have listened to these songs countless times and have done the same with The Clash's and Bad Religion's albums, but everytime I come back to the Bollocks, I wonder why I ever left.  <br /> <br /> <br />\\"They were only in existance for 26 months, only ever released one album, but they changed the face of music forever...\\"  <br /> <br />-  <br /> <br />[...]
B00005JKC3|4.0|I just watched this movie yesterday--because I liked Ang Lee's latest _Brokeback Mountain_. I have another motivation: people have been saying that _The Hulk_ is the one of the worst movies ever made, so I wanted to see how bad that was.   <br /> <br />Then it turned out that this movie is not only entertaining, but also thoughtful. This movie, I personally believe, elevated the status of the comic to something meaningful, which means that \\"ordinary\\" people like us can relate; it touches on a dark desire that we want (?) to resist. It seems that \\"desire\\" is Ang Lee's theme; if you look at his filmography, it is quite consistent. Every movie of his deals with the conflicts as well as unexpected heroism one's desire creates.
0307276902|4.0|After hearing so many good things about this much-hyped book, I checked it out from the library to see what the fuss was all about. I thought it was pretty good; it held my interest and it was a fast read. I did get a bit bogged down in the middle of it since it was the same thing over and over again. Still fascinating though. <br />My major complaint is that (although I have no experience with addictions/rehab centers), many things in the book rang false. Would the airline really let an unescorted guy in Frey's condition board a plane (supposedly with the help of a doctor)??? Would the rehab center really put up with his BS and disrespect of the rules??? Not to mention Frey and the couselor going to pick up Lilly in the crackhouse. And the Mobster asking Frey to be his \\"son\\"? I just can't picture that happening. Conveniently enough, nearly all the main characters in the book are now dead and unable to say what really happened (except the counselors, which by law I'm sure are unable to comment on past patients). <br />But, if you're able to take this book with more than a grain of salt, you might find it's a fascinating read.
B000B0WODA|5.0|Yes, you have heard this band. The single Take Me Out from their 2004 self-titled debut has been everywhere. If you watched almost any sporting event in the last year you heard this Scottish band's big song. It also showed up in all kinds of other places, anywhere that needed a catchy music bed. When your band takes off and you are forced to tour non-stop and find a way to do a follow up it is usually a formula for a big let down on the sophomore release. But the boys with the skinny new wave ties were having none of that! In fact, this album is better than the first.  <br /> <br />Right out of the gate they lay it down, \\"So they say you're trouble boy / Because you like to destroy / All the things that bring idiots joy / Well, what's wrong with a little destruction?\\" In a guitar buzzed, hook filled salvo titled The Fallen the band just kicks into full gear and doesn't let up for six tracks. Do You Want To and You're The Reason I'm Leaving will have you bopping and singing along all day. When the band does slow it down they do so with great effect. The two slower songs, Eleanor Put Your Boots On and Fade Together are wonderfully crafted and serve to bring balance to the disc.  <br /> <br />The real reason this disc is so good is that Franz Ferdinand has learned to more carefully craft their songs. The first disc had lots of songs that abruptly changed direction in mid-stream. Sometimes this worked to perfection (Take Me Out) other times it was a bit jarring and disconnected. Those mid-song changes still occur but they are far less over the top and thus the disc as a whole feels better and works together more effectively. If you like the retro 80s movement in music then this disc should be at the top of your new wave list.
B000002NG7|4.0|8 years after, looking at this album and the career of Faith No More in general still causes me to get a little choked up. I was devastated at that press conference when Billy announced they were splitting. Faith No More was easily one of the top 2 or 3 best bands of the 90's, and it was sad to see them go. Enough weeping, however, let's get into the review. <br /> <br />This album as a whole has a very plodding, exhausted feel to it. One can ascertain the general feeling that these guys are sick of each other (Mike Patton didn't even rehearse with the band, instead turning in his vocal tracks by mail while working on Mr. Bungle's spectacular 1999 release California) and that they know this is the last straw. The songs still stand up on their own, for the most part, and it is still light years more coherent and cohesive than the lackluster 1994 release King For A Day, Fool For a Lifetime. The whole album lends a feeling of distance, of space, a stunning shift from their previous walls-of-sound performances Angel Dust and The Real Thing. Jon Hudson's guitar work is mediocre, yet there are moments (Ashes to Ashes being the most prominent) where his simplistic efforts really enhance, rather than detract, from the material. For a hardcore FNM fan, this is nowhere near their finest material, but for the rest of the industry, it stands head and shoulders above what was available at the time, and in fact still stands taller than most of the material released in the 8 years following.  <br /> <br />The album begins with a bone-jarring syncopated semi-trash number, Collision. While fully loaded with raw power, the overall emotive value of this piece wears off quickly once the initial headbanging is over. No notable lyric here, it's a very sparse hint at a book and movie done a short time before. Stripsearch is a powerful bounceback, both lyrically and musically. Flowing, ethereal textures and incredibly emotive vocal passages, with lines such as \\"In these days - I'm breathing stone - crying stone - I'll win this race - I'll leave alone - arrive alone\\" place this piece among the best this band has ever produced. The radio-ready \\"Last Cup of Sorrow\\" is a flop. Dead, lifeless, unimaginative, boring - frankly I was shocked such a great band could produce such a piece of crap, and then have the gall to release it as a single over some of the real gems on this record. Chalk that one up to the industry pushing a band to re-write its big hit over and over again, as if forcing the same sound down people's throats repeatedly will make them love you. \\"Naked in Front of the Computer\\" brings back the dark humour that has been such a beloved component of this band's sound for years. Jon's opening riff is lackluster, but the song ignores it and moves on into a frantic, aggressive underpinning for some very tasty lyrical gems such as \\"In how many ways - and words - can you say nothing - millions of ways - and words - to say nothing\\" - all a sarcastic stab at the internet revolution and its evolving into what is essentially a forum for dolts such as myself to foam at the mouth to whoever will listen. \\"Helpless\\" is a spectacular quasi-ballad piece with dreamy synth passages, although again weighed down by Hudson's lack of imagination and skill. Quips like \\"For every wish, I wonder why - Why all I want is something beautiful - A place to rest\\" toss the listener rather casually into serious depression, while the eerie whistling and other sound effects hint that the band is laughing at your pain all along. \\"Mouth to Mouth\\" brings more tongue-in-cheek silliness and a brilliant hook \\"I can dress up the dead man - but I can't bring him back to life.\\" Too bad they didn't drop this surefire hit on the general public. \\"Ashes to Ashes\\" is definitely another T-10 alltime FNM piece. Patton's soaring vocals interplay beautifully with Roddy's boards, and Hudson's 14 note guitar solo actually makes for a perfect interlude between segments. The hook is stellar - \\"Smiling with the mouth of the ocean - and I'll wave to you with the arms of the mountain - I'll see you\\" and passionate, one of the few genuinely emotional pieces on the album. \\"She Loves Me Not\\" is a forgettable effort at a show-tune, with Roddy masturbating on a his grand piano patch and Mike desperately trying to bail the song out with some mindbending vocal texturing. \\"Got That Feeling\\" is an ambitious compound time-signature nu-metal piece, which is great if you're a nu-metal band, but rather unfortunate if you're the band who wrote one song that started the whole bloody genre. \\"Paths Of Glory\\" is powerful, grandiose piece with a surprisingly strong hook riff from Hudson and some stunning lyric to support another soaring, intense vocal performance from Patton, with shreds like \\"Is this the only path of glory - If so then I won't go alone - Follow the trail\\" grabbing the listener by the throat and demanding attention. \\"Home Sick Home\\" is a grand little dark-flavored swing piece that could be likened to a Charles Manson comedy tour. Ponder that visual for a minute. \\"Pristina\\" is a beautifully sparse final movement for the album, evoking precisely what I have to believe the band intended - this is it, folks, it's over, we're done. \\"In every dark land - in every flower bed - in every marraige bed - I'll be with you - I'm watching you\\" - what's left to be said? <br /> <br />Overall, a fine coda to a spectacular career for this band. It's completely unfair, really, to hold it up to the standard of Angel Dust - no band in the history of heavy rock has ever managed to eclipse their masterwork ex post facto, why should we expect FNM to have been any different? Still, it stands up on its own and demands to be accounted for in the annals of alt-rock history.
B0009H1CKG|4.0|Stop!  If you don't have the Mothership Connection DVD, I highly recommend buying it first.  Perhaps I'm too old school but, in my opinion, the Mothership Connection DVD captures PFunk at their peak and the Live At Montreux DVD captures PFunk as they are now.  That said, if you already have the Mothership Connection DVD, the Live At Montreux DVD compliments it nicely and both are must haves for your PFunk collection. However, my favorite part of the Live At Montreux DVD are the bonus tracks.  It is worth buying the Live At Montreux DVD if only for Bernie Worrell's synth solo and Michael Hampton's performance of Maggot Brain.  Regardless, I must emphasize buying the Mothership Connection DVD first if you don't already have it.  I just feel it is a superior concert.
0517123207|5.0|Many people assume that Darwin's initial account of natural selection is so out of date that it is to be avoided in favour of more recent text books of evolutionary theory. While it is true that huge gains have been made in the one and a half centuries since the first publication of \\"The Origin\\", there is nothing in this work which is wrong. Darwin was too good a scientist and too cautious.<br /><br />Some claim that Darwin admitted of the possibility of Lamarkian mechanisms. They have not read the original. Darwin knew nothing of the molecular basis of genetics, but knew that natural selection did not need a Lamarkian mechanism. He simply did not rule it out, although he found it improbable. Everything that is stated in this great classic is as true today as it was at the time of first publication.<br /><br />It is also said that Charles Darwin was a lesser intellectual when compared to most other great names of science; that he was a plodder, a naturalist, a sort of gentleman stamp collector who pressed flowers into his books and barely a scientist in the contemporary sense. This is nonsense. Darwin was one of the giants of rigorous systematic thinking; the kind of rigorous thinking and critical attitude that asks the right questions and provides the capacity to answer them. Let me buttress this claim with one example.<br /><br />At the end of chapter six Darwin noted that the theory of natural selection could not account for structures or behaviors found in one species that exist solely for the benefit of another unrelated species. In setting out the theoretical terms for the refutation of the theory in this way, he anticipated Karl Popper, that analytical non-nonsense philosopher of science, by more than a century.<br /><br />I recommend you read this book with an attentive curious analytical mind. You will find yourself walking in the footsteps of an intellectual giant.

They do not distract from this beautiful CD.

B00005ASHM|5.0|Mike Love snidely commented that all this music was silly, superfluous and egotistical- he accused Brian Wilson of recording his own selfish \\"pet sounds\\". Aside from John Lennon- the only other worthy apart from Wilson- the Beatles spent the rest of their days trying to barge into Wilson's universe.<br /><br />I grew up with \\"Pet Sounds\\", in a way, because I did not have a chance to hear it at first, but heard some of it in 1970. B000244FDW|2.0|I have to say that I'm puzzled by the overwhelming support of this adaptation of Jane Austen's book in the face of more recent--and in my opinion, better--adaptations.  Having seen all versions of P&P that I could legally get my hands on, and being a huge fan of the book and its author, I found this version of the story flat and uninteresting...and, dare I say, boring. <br /> <br />David Rintoul had the makings to be an excellent Darcy, but in the end, his performance is a disappointment.  If there is any character development happening here, I must have missed it.  Rintoul struts around the film with a ramrod-straight back and absolutely no emotion or sensitivity; if I had not read the book I would have wondered how Elizabeth possibly managed to fall in love with him.  Granted, Austen focuses very little on the emotions of her heros, but this detachment does not transfer well to screen -- whether Austen addresses it or not, the character of Darcy must change from the first proposal to the second, and this is something the production team of the '95 BBC adaptation understood.  Whether direction was at fault in this production, or simply Rintoul's personal interpretation of the role, this is a very unsatisfying portrayal. <br /> <br />Elizabeth Garvie gives a good effort, but she simply does not have the wit and vivacity of Ehle's Elizabeth.  Again, as with Rintoul, there was much potential here.  In combination with Rintoul's Darcy, this insipid portrayal points to a lack of vision on the production team, more specifically the direction.  I get the feeling that both of these actors had much to give if they had been allowed to give it.  The overall production tries to stick as closely as possible to Austen's Pride and Prejudice, but in the obsession with details, it loses the overall feel and tone of the book.  \\"Couldn't see the forest for the trees\\" has relevancy here. <br /> <br />If you'd like to see a truly good adaptation of the novel, go for the 1995 production, also done by the BBC.  True, it's everyone's favorite, but that's for a reason.

1932100385|5.0|This is a fantastic book that's loaded with so much eye opening information, it's the kind of book that I'll read again. I feel if you don't convert to a whole food plant based diet after reading this book, I don't think anything in the world will convince you....the evidence is just overwhelming.  <br /> <br /> <br />As for my story, I was on statins for high cholesterol for over 6 years....and a moderate to high dose at that. Over the years, my cholesterol kept rising gradually and my total cholesterol was just over 300 and a triglyceride level in the mid 200's without statins. The moderate/high dose statin brought my cholesterol down to the range of high 190's to low 200's. Over the years, I tried to get off the medication and I was told to try to eat a low fat diet, don't eat shrimp, lobster, etc. I went off the statins, tried this diet for several months and none of this helped....actually my cholesterol went higher....I was told it's hereditary, there's nothing you can do, and I should take the statin and that I would be on them indefinitely. Well, after reading the book \\"The China Study\\", there's a few paragraphs tucked in this great book mentioning that the major factor causing high cholesterol is eating any animal protein. The only meat I ate at the time was fish and chicken and small portions of it....and maybe beef a few times a year, if that. I have to say I was skeptical and figured what do I have to lose, so I went on a whole food plant based diet (vegan diet)as Dr. Campbell in the book suggests. I started that last November (same time I stopped taking the statins), and I had my cholesterol checked this past summer and was stunned at the result....my total cholesterol went from over 300 without statins, high 190's/low 200's on moderate/high does statin, to 175 without statins on Vegan diet, with good LDL and HDL. I'm guessing next time it's checked it will be even lower. Also, my triglycerides went from the mid 200's to 64! All as a result of just giving up animal products....amazing. Now I wonder....why wasn't I ever given this option by the doctor's I've seen over the years? Even if a person doesn't want to give up animal products completely as I have, why isn't this advice offered as at least an option to a patient.....and let the patient decide? What a concept! <br /> <br />Of course, I feel my cholesterol and triglycerides levels are just the tip of the iceberg on how my health has improved on a plant based diet....the only regret?....I wish I started the vegan diet earlier....I never have had so much energy and just downright have never felt so good....seriously...this is not an overstatement. <br /> <br />As to all the doubters out there with harsh reviews, I say to each is own but ignore the evidence at your own risk. I've seen many of my friends and family sick by what I feel this book has proven by many studies to be nothing more than a bad diet for the most part and most of them are looking for a magic pill to save them....and the old standby argument that it's all genetic doesn't appear to hold much water either....again, proven by studies in the book. <br /> <br />My friend, family, and co-workers know how I eat now and wonder why I want to live forever....that's not the issue....quality of life over quantity of life...isn't this what we should all be after?

B00005JOIF|3.0|In 1972, the world was shocked at an act of terrorism played out on the world stage of the Munich Olympics, when a group of Arab terrorists, known as Black September, kidnapped the Israeli Olympic team from their rooms in the Olympic village, and ultimately killed them all.<br /><br />Faced with this act, and after their defeat of their enemies in the 1967-1969 struggle for their homeland against Arab foes, the country of Israel decides to seek retribution against the 11 men who were involved in the planning of the killings. They struggle with the decision, and the principal of seeking vengeance, but decide they must. They choose, as their instrument, a young Sabra, born in Israel to a hero of Israeli independence. Avram (played by Eric Bana), the young Israeli, was once a bodyguard to Prime Minister Golda Meir. He is impeccably well trained and trustworthy. He absorbs with aplomb the news that he is to be an assassin, to lead an assassination team for the Mossad, and that he will be disavowed by his government if he is caught. His team, four men, is provided to him, along with copious amounts of money to complete his task. His handler, Ephraim (Geoffrey Rush in another brilliant performance) is imperious and demanding.<br /><br />The story is absorbing, the nature of the events shocking, the performances supporting Bana's are very well done. Bana himself is a revelation, and this film should make him a household word.  He is marvelous in his role.  Spielberg ultimately elects NOT to present the film as a justification for what Israel did, but a message about the consequences of seeking an eye for an eye.  He plants seeds of doubt throughout the film, and it is obvious that he has either struggled with his belief that what was done was necessary, OR, he may support what was done, but just want to be more politically correct in delivering his message...that violence to cure violence never works.<br /><br />I think Spielberg has produced a fine film, and perhaps one worthy of four stars and a whole lot of heated conversation about the outcomes.  The violence is shocking, the message is somewhat unclear...the film runs long, but it is ultimately a thriller of the highest standing, with an ending that leaves the filmgoer unsatisfied.<br /><br />But I'm giving the film three stars, and that is reflective of the overall effort, less the absolutely appalling scene where the final film of what happened to the Israeli Olympics team is interspersed with Avram's reunion with his wife in their bed.  I found the juxtaposition of these film slices to be the most shameless and ridiculous film stunt I've seen in a long, long time.  Spielberg should be ashamed of this contrivance.  And this single episode far and away detracts from what should have been an important film.<br /><br />While dodging the bullets of his detractors who will cry false at the \\"violence never works\\" precept, Spielberg did the unthinkable; allowed himself to edit and present in a way that absolutely cheapened the overall effort.  Disappointing.nd perhaps one worthy of four stars and a whole lot of heated conversation about the outcomes.  The violence is shocking, the message is somewhat unclear...the film runs long, but it is ultimately a thriller of the highest standing, with an ending that leaves the filmgoer unsatisfied.   <br /> <br />But I'm giving the film three stars, and that is reflective of the overall effort, less the absolutely appalling scene where the final film of what happened to the Israeli Olympics team is interspersed with Avram's reunion with his wife in their bed.  I found the juxtaposition of these film slices to be the most shameless and ridiculous film stunt I've seen in a long, long time.  Spielberg should be ashamed of this contrivance.  And this single episode far and away detracts from what should have been an important film.   <br /> <br />While dodging the bullets of his detractors who will cry false at the \\"violence never works\\" precept, Spielberg did the unthinkable; allowed himself to edit and present in a way that absolutely cheapened the overall effort. B000002J6F|4.0|Alright: it's always a problem to approach an album that's being pushed as \\"classic\\" or \\"best\\". At best, we are robbed of the pleasure of discovery; at worst, we find ourselves wondering why we don't \\"get it\\". Such is the baggage of critical acclaim.<br /><br />Stephen Stills made a lot of albums, and any person experiencing them now for the first time is at a serious disadvantage. All those who crow about events 30 years past simply can't convey them to the younger generations; past experience is necessarily subjective. There is simply no way to communicate the experience of being a young adult in the early 70s if you did not live through it, and any young music-lover today can only infer that there must have been SOMETHING going on by the fact that 1975 marked a strong change from what had gone before.<br /><br />So where does this leave MANASSAS? As observed by another reviewer below, MANASSAS is not strong on radio-friendly singles. It does not mark a stylistic change, let alone set any new trends. It did not outsell Stephen's other albums. In fact, it has only recently gained any particular notice. What's up?<br /><br />The early 70s saw the rise of something that no longer exists: AOR, or Album Oriented Radio. The Beatles had, following Dylan's example, shown that album songs could have a value of their own without being either singles or throwaway filler. In other words, they showed that you could trust the record-buying audience to appreciate good music that wasn't necessarily hit material. Roots material, especially, could be solid compositions without having hit potential. MANASSAS is an album that understood that. Oh sure -- there is a single (\\"Johnny's Garden\\"), but these songs don't really cry out for airplay. That doesn't matter.<br /><br />What this album has on almost every track is staying power. Here, Stills & company trust the listener to hear the heart in these songs without the production, without speeding things up, without assuming our attentions will wander if not enticed every 3.5 seconds. Think EXILE ON MAIN STREET and you'll see what I mean; the music we like most in the long run isn't necesarily what we like first.<br /><br />Stills had built a considerable career on music that used but muted his Southern, blues and Latin influences; here, he gives them full rein, while twisting them all to his own purpose -- and performed by a band that could really do them all justice. Consequently MANASSAS, more than any other SS album, shows the depth and breadth of Stephen's musical vision. Other albums would allow him personally to do more (his first solo outing; the first CSN album) but this one nails every peg square on the head: rock, commercial pop, electric blues, Cuban bluegrass [?!], real bluegrass, country, gospel [!!], folk, easy listening, Latin, commercial folk-rock ... this, really, is the kind of complete musical statement we want every artist to make.<br /><br />-- Which, with the help of a tremendous array of talented musicians, he does. DOWN THE ROAD is more of the same, with a narrower scope and not divided into categories. After that, Stephen seemed content to just make commercial product without really caring what it was. But MANASSAS was a distinct reaction to 1972, to what people were trying to live through, to what Stephen had (or had not) been and could yet be. Give it a few spins yourself & see if (over time) you don't agree.ur attentions will wander if not enticed every 3.5 seconds. Think EXILE ON MAIN STREET and you'll see what I mean; the music we like most in the long run isn't necesarily what we like first.   <br /> <br />Stills had built a considerable career on music that used but muted his Southern, blues and Latin influences; here, he gives them full rein, while twisting them all to his own purpose -- and performed by a band that could really do them all justice. Consequently MANASSAS, more than any other SS album, shows the depth and breadth of Stephen's musical vision. Other albums would allow him personally to do more (his first solo outing; the first CSN album) but this one nails every peg square on the head: rock, commercial pop, electric blues, Cuban bluegrass [?!], real bluegrass, country, gospel [!!], folk, easy listening, Latin, commercial folk-rock ... this, really, is the kind of complete musical statement we want every artist to make.  <br /> <br />-- Which, with the help of a tremendous array of talented musicians, he does. DOWN THE ROAD is more of the same, with a narrower scope and not divided into categories. After that, Stephen seemed content to just make commercial product without really caring what it was. But MANASSAS was a distinct reaction to 1972, to what people were trying to live through, to what Stephen had (or had not) been and could yet be. Give it a few spins yourself & see if (over time) you don't agree.
